coredata.dc:title: Cu K-edge XANES of Cu(II) ions in aqueous solution: A measure of the axial ligand distances
coredata.dc:creator: Onori, G.
Santucci, A.
Scafati M. Belli, A.
Della Longa, S.
Bianconi, A.
Palladino, L.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) of a Cu(II) ion in NaOH solution (2 M) has been measured and compared with Cu(II) ions in aqueous solution. The spectra have been analyzed using multiple scattering theory. All spectral features have been interpreted in terms of one-electron transitions and the distance of axial ligands has been quantitatively determined byXANES. There is no need to invoke shake down or shake up effects at the Cu K-edge.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 August 1988 Volume 149, number 3 Cu K-EDGE XANES OF Cu(1I) IONS IN AQUEOUS SOLUTION: A MEASURE OF THE AXIAL LIGAND DISTANCES G. ONORI, A. SANTUCCI Dipartimento di Fisica, Universita di Perugia and JNFN, Sezione Perugia, 06100 Perugia, Italy A. SCAFATI, M. BELL! Laboratorio di Fisica, 1st it uto Superiore di Sanitd and INFI !, Sezione Sanita, 00161 Rome, Italy S. DELLA LONGA, A. BIANCONI Gruppo Nazionale di Cibernetica e Biofisica (GNCB), Dipartimento di Fisica, Universith di Roma, La Sapienza, 00185 Rome. Italy and L. PALLADINO Dipartimento di Fisica, Universita dell Aquila and INFN, LNF, 67100 L Aquila, Italy Received 3 May 1988; in final form 26 May 1988 The K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) of a Cu (II) ion in NaOH solution (2 M) has been measured and compared with Cu (II) ions in aqueous solution. The spectra have been analyzed using multiple scattering theory. All spectral features have been interpreted in terms of one-electron transitions and the distance of axial ligands has been quantitatively deter- mined by XANES. There is no need to invoke shakedown or shake up effects at the Cu K-edge. 1. Introduction Cupric complexes (3d9 electronic structure) may exist as hexa-, penta-, and tetra-coordinated species. Because of the Jahn Teller effect hexa-coordinated Cu( II) species show appreciably distorted octahed- ral structures [1]. This tetragonal distortion is well established in crystal structures of various copper (II) hydrates [2 5]. It is believed to exist also for the [Cu (H20 ) 6 2 + cluster in aqueous solutions because of Cu U bond stretching along one axis driven by the dynamical Jahn Teller effect. Recent X-ray dif- fraction studies have clearly shown the existence of distorted coordination polyhedra around Cu(II) in aqueous solutions of Cu(CIU4)2 [6,7], CuSU4 [8], Also at Universita deII Aquila, Dipartimento STBB, ColIc- maggio, L Aquila, Italy. and Cu(NU3)2 [9]. Un the other hand, the exis- tence of two different coordination distances for Cu (11) water pairs was not evident in an X-ray dif- fraction study of copper(II) perchlorate solutions [10]. Direct physical measurement of structural param- eters by X-ray and neutron diffraction is only ap- plicable to electrolyte solutions at high concentrations (greater than 1 M) but in these conditions presum- ably, a large fraction of the ions are not simple hy- drated ions but complexes [11]. The use of synchrotron radiation offers the possibility for the application of high-resolution X-ray absorption spectroscopy in dilute solutions to probe the Jahn Teller distortion. However, the two bond lengths were not clearly resolved from the extended X-ray ab- sorption fine structure (EXAFS) [12] using plane wave analysis. 0 009-2614/88/S 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 289 Volume 149, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 August 1988 By changing the focus from the high-energy EXAFS range to the low-energy range, the absorption spectra exhibit X-ray absorption near-edge structures (XANES) [13]. This is determined by multiple scattering processes of the excited photoelectron with neighbouring atoms and is sensitive to the local elec- tronic and geometric environment of the absorbing atom. Theoretical advances in the use of multiple scattering theory [14 17] to determine the pho- toabsorption cross section in real space allows a quantitative interpretation of the XANES spectra to determine the stereochemistry around a metal site. It has been shown that Cu (II) XANES spectra are sensitive to different axial bond lengths in Cu oc- tahedral sites [18 20]. In previous work [18] on CuC12 in aqueous solution and on Cu (II) complexes with adenosine triphosphate (ATP) in solution at various pH values, the analysis of XANES spectra allowed us to identify distortions from octahedral coordination in dilute solutions (typically 10 mM). In a study of Cu(II) ions in solutions [19] and in superoxide dismutase [201 the sensitivity of XANES to tetragonal site distortion was found. In this work we have attempted a quantitative de- termination of the Jahn Teller distortion for Cu (II) ions in dilute solution by XANES. The high-reso- lution Cu K-edge XANES spectrum has been mea- sured and extensive multiple scattering calculations have been performed to fit the experimental data us- ing the oxygen axial distance as a free parameter. Another object of our investigation is the study of the Cu site structure for a Cu (II) ion in 2 M NaUH solution in which a soluble complex is formed that an ESR study [21] indicates as [Cu(OH)4]2 with an approximately square planar structure. In the interpretation of the Cu (II) XANES there is a long-standing problem in the assignment of a peak on the Cu K-edge absorption rising edge to a mul- tiple scattering process or to a many-body (shake down) process [22]. Polarized Cu K-edge XANES spectra of square planar Cu complexes [23 25] have demonstrated that the shoulder on the rising edge is due to a core transition observed only when the elec- tric field is in the z direction. Some authors have in- terpreted these findings as evidence for a shake-down effect [24,25]. Here we show that all spectral features of the XANES spectrum of the square planar complex, in- eluding the shoulder on the absorption rising edge, can be interpreted using one-electron multiple scat- tering theory, there being no need to invoke multi- electron effects such as shake down . In fact this shoulder is determined by the polarized electric field EIIz absorption due to multiple scattering of two ax- ial oxygen atoms at 2.8 A on the z axis. These ions arc sufficiently distant to be unobservable in ESR spectra but they can be detected by XANES. 2. Experimental 30 mM solutions of CuC12 were prepared from re- agent grade CuCI2 6H2U in doubly distilled H2U and in 2 M NaUH. The X-ray absorption spectra at the K-edge of cop- per were collected at the wiggler beam line PWA (Project Wiggler ADUNE) of the ADUNE storage ring in Frascati. X-rays were monochromatized with a high-resolution Si (111) channel cut crystal mono- chromator, with a 1 mm entrance slit 30 m from the source. The higher-order harmonics were suppressed by changing the current in the electromagnetic poles of the wiggler. The liquid samples were contained in special Te- flon cells with Kapton windows, 2 mm thick; the measurements were performed immediately after preparation of the solutions, at room temperature. The energy resolution was about 1.5 eV and the XANES spectra were recorded using 0.5 eV energy steps. In the analysis of the XANES, the pre-edge back- ground was subtracted, and the absorption coeffi- cient was normalized to the high energy value, about 100 eV above the edge. The energy zero of the ab- sorption spectra was taken as the energy of the pre- edge peak P shown in fig. 1. 3. Results and discussion In fig. I we report the XANES spectra and their derivatives for Cu (II) ions in aqueous solution and in 2 M NaUH, at the same Cu concentration. Peak P is due to a ls *3d Cu transition, which is dipole forbidden. Peak A on the rising edge can be identified in the derivative spectra and is well re 290 Volume 149, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 August 1988 C,) LU z .( C 0 9030 Fig. 1. Experimental XANES spectrum (E) and its derivative (X ) for Cu(II) ions in aqueous solution (left) and for Cu(II) ions in 2 M NaOH solution (right). solved in NaOH solution because of the larger sep- aration between A and B spectral features. We observe a red-shift of peak A in NaUH solution while the energy of the absorption maximum B does not change. Moreover a new peak C is observed. The en- ergy positions of the observed features are reported in table 1. We have analyzed the experimental data by using the multiple scattering XANES program of Durham et al. [15]. In the XANES calculations the final states are generated by the multiple scattering (MS-X) procedure. The muffin-tin approximation has been used to describe the potential; the radii of the muf- fin-tin potential for copper, ~ and for oxygen, R0, have been determined by looking for convergence of the intersphere constant potential V by varying the muffin-tin radii. Considering the shortest Cu U dis- tance as d, the muffin-tin radii for copper, ~ and Table I for oxygen, R0_ d R0~, have been determined by changing R and imposing the condition that the two muffin-tin potentials should assume the same value V~~(R) = V0(d R) at the touching point R of the two muffin-tin spheres. This value of the potential will be the constant intersphere potential V. The muffin-tin radius of the two axial oxygens has been taken to be the same as the other oxygens. The phase shifts for the scattering process have been generated for each different CuU4U2 cluster with different Cu U axial bond length. We started our analysis with model calculations for a CuUe cluster by changing the Cu U distance and considering a tetragonal distortion. The effect of this distortion induces a large dichroism in the XANES spectra. The polarized spectrum with the electric field E parallel to the equatorial (x, y) plane is the same as that for E]z for a symmetrical CuU6 Energy shifts with respect to the ls .3d Cu transition for the peaks observed in the XANES spectra and their derivatives Solution Derivative AE, ~b Absorption AEA ~B aEc Cu(II) aqueous 2 M NaOH 5.2 12.5 7.6 18.1 21.5 Cu(II) aqueous 10.3 15.3 12.8 18.1 8980 8990 9000 9010 9020 9030 ENERGY (cv) 8990 9000 ENERGY (eV) 291 Volume 149, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 August 1988 cluster, but considering clusters with different Cu U axial distances along the z direction, the E(Iz spec- trum shows a large variation. In fig. 2a we report the different spectra for several Cu U axial bond lengths from 2.0 to 3.8 A. Peak A in these spectra moves towards low energies as the axial distance increases. In fig. 2b the calculated en- ergy position of peak A as a function of 1 /R2 is plot- ted. From fig. 2b it appears that the energy of this multiple-scattering resonance follows the 1 /.R2 rule [26], which is the expected trend for a small vari- ation of the interatomic distance in the energy-in- dependent phase-shift approximation. It is interesting to note that this rule is followed over a large range of Cu U distances. In contrast the spectrum for E z (in the equa- torial plane) is not affected by elongation of the ax- ial distance: in fact the main absorption peak B remains at the same energy if there are no changes in the equatorial Cu U bonds. The fact that peak B in the experimental spectra of the two samples does not show any significant energy shift indicates that the bond distances in the equatorial plane are unchanged. The calculated spectra reported in fig. 3 have been obtained by looking for the best agreement between the calculated and experimental derivative spectra, leaving as free parameter the axial Cu U bond. It is well known that the XANES calculations give only qualitative agreement with the experimental spectra as regards the amplitudes of the absorption peaks. Use of the derivative spectra reduces the difficulty in predicting experimental amplitudes. The equatorial bond length has been fixed at 1.95 A to account for the main peak B. By changing the axial distance in steps of 0.05 A in the range 2.0 4.3 A, we have found the best fit at 2.38 0.05 A in the spectrum of Cu(II) in aqueous solution and 2.8 0.05 A for Cu(II) in NaOH solution. The er- rors have been estimated from the fact that a change of 0.02 A in the axial distance gives an appreciable disagreement between experimental data and the calculated values. A second source of error in the es- timation of absolute distances is the muffin-tin ap- proximation. By changing the muffin-tin radii of copper and oxygen we found a change in the phase shifts and amplitudes and we estimate that the error on the distances from this source is of the order of 0.05 A. We found the best fit using 1.08 and 0.88 A for the muffin-tin radii of Cu and U, respectively. In conclusion we have reported for the first time a fitting of the derivative of the XANES spectra of Cu (II) in solution and have obtained a quantitative measure of the axial bond lengths by XANES. (a) Calculated polarized XANES spectra for a Cu05 cluster with four oxygens in the (x, y) plane at a fixed Cu O distance of 1.96 A, and two oxygens on the z axis at different Cu O distances d~. Spectra with the electric fieldEparallel to the taxis: d, =2.2 A (dashed line); d2= 2.8 A (thick dots); d3=3.3 A (dash-dotted line); d4= 3.8 A (solid line); d5=square planar (light dots). (b) Shift tiE of the peak A as a function of 1 /R2, where R is the axial Cu O distance. 292 Volume 149, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 August 1988 z 0 0- 0 CO C shoulder A in the absorption rising edge of Cu com- plexes can be described as a multiple-scattering res- onance. The fact that the ESR spectra for Cu( II) in NaUH solution indicated only a square planar co- ordination for the Cu (II) sites may be due to the fact that the axial oxygen distance of 2.8 A is so long that it does not affect the ESR signal. head.ce:title: Cu K-edge XANES of Cu(II) ions in aqueous solution: A measure of the axial ligand distances

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) of a Cu(II) ion in NaOH solution (2 M) has been measured and compared with Cu(II) ions in aqueous solution. The spectra have been analyzed using multiple scattering theory. All spectral features have been interpreted in terms of one-electron transitions and the distance of axial ligands has been quantitatively determined byXANES. There is no need to invoke shake down or shake up effects at the Cu K-edge.
